newsitem.title: USA: Mass. leaders agree to cut unemployment insurance.
newsitem.headline: Mass. leaders agree to cut unemployment insurance.

text.p: Massachusetts Acting Governor Paul Cellucci said state leaders agreed on Thursday to cut the state's unemployment insurance rate by two steps, saving employers an estimated $194 million per year.
"This is great news for the economy of Massachusetts," Cellucci told reporters. "It represents about a $194 million tax cut for employers. That means we can keep Massachusetts competitive."

Cellucci and leaders from the House and Senate agreed to the tax cut just as the Department of Employment and Training was about to release a report showing that the unemployment trust fund shows a healthy balance of $1.2 billion.

The cut, effective January 1, 1998, will decrease the unemployment insurance rate two full steps to "schedule C", at which rate employers pay an average of $400 per employee per year, from "schedule E", which averages $488 per employee each year.
"This is very important for our economy, it's very important for the workers of Massachusetts," Cellucci said.
